text.p: These are the leading stories in the Turkish press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Islamists deputies opposed to eight years of compulsory education that would lead to the closure of religious school curse the plan despite public approval of the measure from their leader, Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan.
- Leftist opposition leader Bulent Ecevit holds consultations with party leaders in bid for new government formula if the current Islamist-led governemnt is toppled.

- Erbakan fails to reply to three parliamentary motions, pending for 204 days, questioning his relations with Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi. Erbakan had a scandalous visit to Libya in October of 1996.
- Bussinessmen are pessimistic in face of ongoing political instability that blocks long-term projects and investment.

- Erbakan acknowledges -- but does not sign -- draft bill extending compulsory secular education to eight years before presenting it to his cabinet. The bill has been target of fierce criticism from Erbakan's fellow Islamists.
- Young girls in boarding school allege they were beaten for the putting on pairs of jeans, seen as a "sin" by the dormitory authority in conservative southeastern province of Sanliurfa.
- Ankara signs natural gas deal with Russia for delivery of 18 billion cubic meters, running until 2002.
- The anniversary of the birth of the Prophet Mohammad is being celebrated for a week.
